pr_title: KOGITO-1204 - BPMN editor to support "expression" in Data IO on process side

timeline.message: KOGITO-1204 - BPMN editor to support "expression" in Data IO on process side

timeline.bodyText: I think it is better to create the Pattern object as an static field in this class, This way you can just call Pattern#match(s) passing the test string, and the pattern is already pre-compiled only once.
timeline.author: romartin

timeline.bodyText: The JIRA was expecting two options on the dropdown: constant and expression. So before merging, we should clarify if doing this way is still fine for eveyone.
timeline.author: romartin

replies.bodyText: This is marshallers part we need to do it on server side anyway despite of how it will be handled on the UI part.
replies.author: hasys

timeline.bodyText:
By doing this you're converting the "checked" exception UnsupportedEncodingException into an "unchecked" one of type IllegalArgumentException. This results a bit "dangerous" because the signature for the decode method does not provide any exception information, but the decode can still fail, right? By doing this, actually it'll just thow an IllegalArgumentException and maybe it appears on the UI, but it's not really useful for the end user.
I was maybe expecting this decode method throwing the exception, and the caller for it catching the exception too, this way you can show a validation error to the user.
But again, not sure if makes completely sense, it depends on how to use it....
timeline.author: romartin

replies.bodyText: This catch UnsupportedEncodingException since we have encoding as not changing literal it should work without issues.
replies.author: hasys

replies.bodyText: but I mean, if that IllegalArgumentException is being thrown at some point... what wil happen to the end user? does the exception will end up on the UI? does the field keep working properly? I'm just concerned about there this exception will end up....
replies.author: romartin

I think it safe enough, since to get this error you need to modify and recompile the code (no user will do it) and also change literal to incorrect value and ignore the failing test.
replies.author: hasys

replies.bodyText: We can ignore this exception and return empty value, for an instance and in this case in worse case user will lose only value for this property, but it will be very hard to debug.
replies.author: hasys

replies.bodyText: Anyway user can do nothing to fix incorrect literal, because to fix it you need to modify the code and rebuild business central. So I am not sure how useful fancy message will be for the end user if someone will change for any reason this literal to incorrect one.
replies.author: hasys

timeline.bodyText: maybe here happens the same issue as on the decode method above - around un/checked exceptions..
timeline.author: romartin

replies.bodyText: This catch UnsupportedEncodingException since we have encoding as not changing literal it should work without issues.
replies.author: hasys

timeline.bodyText:
Is there really a need to mock the VariableDeclaration object? In general, for domain objects (with no logic around) there is no need to mock the instances, it just makes the test more complex...
If possible, please try to use the new operator, create the "real" instance, and if necessary, just spy on it.
timeline.author: romartin

timeline.message:
Fixed test.

Assignments are encoded on UI side and decoded on the backend side and saved as CDATA or expression, so string should be encoded in this test.
Source/Target change
KOGITO-1204 - BPMN editor to support "expression" in Data IO on process side
make patters client a backend compatible
GWT on client side marshallers compatibility

Fixed test.

Assignments are encoded on UI side and decoded on the backend side and saved as CDATA or expression, so string should be encoded in this test.
Source/Target change
KOGITO-1209 - VSCode - BPMN modeler escape in data input
KOGITO-1209 - VSCode - BPMN modeler escape in data input

timeline.bodyText: why not moving this static final Pattern instance to the new Patterns class you just created? So htis way, the expression (String) will be compiled just once, instead of creating a new Pattern instance in every place you need it, and so also having to compile the string expression too.
timeline.author: romartin

replies.bodyText: It is because I can't reuse Pattern in GWT and classic java pattern, both have different implementations. It looks like the String is the only thing I can keep in shared code.
replies.author: hasys

timeline.bodyText: I would just use a Pattern instance here as well, so the expression will be only compiled once. See above comments too about this.
timeline.author: romartin

+
+    public static final String EXPRESSION = "^#\\{(.+)}$";

replies.bodyText: It is because I can't reuse Pattern in GWT and classic java pattern, both have different implementations. It looks like the String is the only thing I can keep in shared code.
replies.author: hasys

replies.bodyText: ahh good point, it's a "shared" class sorry, I didn't noticed before. You're right, all good @hasys thanks!
replies.author: romartin

timeline.bodyText: instead of mocking, it's better to use "real" model objects on tests, if possible.
timeline.author: romartin

replies.bodyText: Yes, I agree, but it has protected constructor and it is not possible to instantiate DataOutputImpl from our tests.
replies.author: hasys

timeline.bodyText: minor comment  - maybe results more clear to use if / else instead of adding a return keyword here...
timeline.author: romartin
